article.title: Characteristics of Sustained >100 MeV Gamma-ray Emission Associated with Solar Flares

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the top panel of Figure 1 show?
choices: Time history of the pion-decay γ-ray count rate revealing a single, continuous phase of emission.
The count rate observed in the 511 keV annihilation line, clearly dominating over the pion-decay count rate.
γ-ray spectra observed only during the impulsive phase of the flare.
Time history of the pion-decay γ-ray count rate revealing two distinct phases of emission.

multiple_choice_question.text: What key difference does the inset of Figure 3 highlight regarding the SGRE event compared to the 1982 June 3 event?
choices: The SGRE event starts simultaneously with the impulsive flare.
The SGRE event starts significantly later than the impulsive flare, with a delay of about six hours.
The SGRE event is much shorter in duration than the impulsive flare.
The associated flare was an X-class event, similar to the June 3 flare.

multiple_choice_question.text: What conclusion can be drawn from the analysis of the count spectrum presented in Figure 4?
choices: The SGRE can be explained by electron bremsstrahlung, as evident from the good fit of the dashed curve.
The proton spectrum responsible for the SGRE follows a single power-law across all energies.
The SGRE spectrum can be explained by pion-decay, suggesting protons are the primary agents of γ-ray production.
The photon spectrum does not steepen above 1 GeV, indicating a single power-law proton spectrum.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the filled circles in Figure 6 represent?
choices: Events where the accompanying flares did not emit hard X-rays exceeding 100 keV.
Events where only upper limits could be obtained for the SEP fluxes due to a stronger preceding event.
Events where the accompanying flares emitted hard X-rays that exceeded 100 keV.
Events where SGRE was observed, irrespective of the hard X-ray emission.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the formula dN/dE ∝ E−sp represent?
choices: The energy spectrum of electrons responsible for bremsstrahlung emission.
The relationship between the CME speed and the SEP proton flux.
The power-law spectrum of accelerated protons.
The time history of the pion-decay γ-ray count rate.
